questions.question_text:
A technician needs to edit a protected .dll file but cannot find the file in the System32 directory.
Which of the following Control Panel utilities should the technician use?

discussion.content: Folder options to show hidden files

questions.question_text: When hackers execute code against a vulnerability in the hope that it has not yet been addressed, this is known as a:

discussion.content: Zero Day - first time vulnerability that ISN'T known
Answer should be “B” I feel like...

comments.content: it cant be B because its your job as a technician to fix the problem.
for me the answer is D becuase you have to figure it out first what is the impact how long the downtime will be etc and second step is let users be aware of how long teh downtime will be.
agree with (B). Feel like you would report the issue before you create an action plan and implement the solution. especially if it will cause a major disruption to workflow.

discussion.content: D, I believe ...he already Identified the issue and its impact to the business.

Pretty sure it is B, because he already identified the issue (outage) and the impact (the potential major disruption in workflow). D doesn't make sense because we don't know what his role is other than monitoring for outages apparently.

I believe the correct answer is also B because the steps for Incident Management per Dion is 

Identify the issue
Report to the proper channel
Preserve the data

I think the answer is A, because the questions is pointing towards DDos attack, hence the technician needs to identify whether it really is a DDOS attack or a simple DOS or anything else before moving forward

I can see how its A. The question states the symptom (an outage) but not the cause (ISP down, Power outage, hardware failure, etc.) and what the repercussions would be (lack of server access, file corruption, network failure etc.)
From there I agree with dsatt, its how your business is structured and what the cause is. My boss would be responsible for recommending a solution to stakeholders but he would be open to my recommendation. If its quick turnaround, that can be him telling the uppers and me fighting with the ISP company and sending message updates.
It depends on how your org is structured, just because you ARE a technician doesn't mean you are THE technician responsible.

choices.B: Report the incident to the proper teams or management for awareness
choices.C: Start a root cause analysis and create documentation
choices.D: Create an action plan and implement the solution
choices.A: Identify the issue and its impact to the business

questions.question_text: A technician is monitoring a network and notices an outage has occurred that could potentially cause a major disruption to the business workflow. Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

discussion.content: Actually it says "control panel utilities" so is that any of the choices?

comments.content:
Yes, control panel utilities would be 
also, the correct answer as control panel>small icon view will have File Explorer Options

discussion.content: How does that "resolve" the issue though? Don't you have to use Task Manager to end the process, delete, antivirus scan, etc?

comments.content: The file is a .bat file renamed to be disguised as a .jpg file. In folder options you can enable File name extensions then the file would appear as .jpg.bat

questions.question_text: A technician is scheduled to upgrade a grocery store's network equipment at 11:00 p.m. There are only a few shoppers in the store; therefore, the store manager wants the technician to start the upgrade early. Which of the following is the NEXT step the technician should perform?

choices.D: Get approval from the Change Advisory Board
choices.A: Create a back-out plan for the store

discussion.content:
A and C would have been done before the technician even showed up onsite.

D seems unlikely as getting an answer from the change advisory board at almost 11PM is bit of a stretch.

That leaves us B - review change request document - i.e. make the manager give you the instruction in writing. MAKE him supply you with a change request stating the reason he wants the upgrade to start early, then if there is any comeback later on you have a signed document stating you were asked to do this by the client.

comments.content: I agree and great explanations. D would take too long and would make the early start pointless.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
its 11pm the advisory board are in bed!

Selected Answer: D
By default, an object inherits permissions from its parent object, either at the time of creation or when it is copied or moved to its parent folder. The only exception to this rule occurs when you move an object to a different folder on the same volume. In this case, the original permissions are retained.

See this link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/windows-security/permissions-on-copying-moving-files
realistically B is the answer because it's pointless for D with the short timeframe but this is also CompTIA, these bastards don't care

comments.content:
As the upgrade is already scheduled, and now just pushed a bit forward, there should be already a backout plan exist!
So no need to do this again
A and C will have been done long before the tech arrives. The tech is there to do the job, not remake documentation.
